item.title: Circana Reveals Best-Selling PlayStation Games of All Time
item.content:encoded:
It's the original PlayStation's 30th anniversary today (for the US release, at the very least), and US sales analysis firm Circana has compiled a list of the brand's best-selling games since 1995 by way of celebration.

As always, we have the ever-reliable Mat Piscatella to thank for sharing this data on social media platform Bluesky, and the list he's compiled is an interesting one, although you probably won't be too surprised by a lot of the names you see.

Obviously, eternal moneyspinner Grand Theft Auto V tops the chart; it is, after all, a release that spans three PlayStation generations, and given the massive popularity of Grand Theft Auto as a franchise (as well as previously-reported sales figures for the game), GTA V's presence probably won't shock you.

According to Piscatella's data, there are no games from the original PlayStation era on the top 20 list, and only three were released on the PlayStation 2. Two of those are GTA titles as well, namely San Andreas and Vice City, while the third is Guitar Hero III: Legends of Rock.

All of the others are PlayStation 3 releases or later. In second place, it's the 2019 version of Call of Duty: Modern Warfare, with third place going to another Rockstar game in the form of Red Dead Redemption II.

Places four through six are occupied by Call of Duty releases as well, and blocky sandbox hit Minecraft is in seventh. Rounding out the top ten are Call of Duty: Black Ops III, then the aforementioned San Andreas and Guitar Hero III.

It's worth noting that all of this is based on dollar sales; the unit sales column looks a little different, but there still aren't any original PlayStation games on it, and even fewer PS2 games appear on the unit sales list.

It also happens to be the Sega Dreamcast's 26th birthday today, and to celebrate, Piscatella has compiled a list of that platform's top 20 best-selling games in the US as well.

Believe it or not, when it comes to dollar sales, Sonic Adventure doesn't top the chart (although it does top the unit sales list). That honor goes to NFL 2K, with successor NFL 2K1 taking second place (followed by Sonic Adventure, naturally).

The Dreamcast may be dead, but many of the franchises on Piscatella's list, including Sonic, Shenmue, and even Crazy Taxi, are still around today. Both lists are well worth a look if you want to take a trip down memory (card) lane.

item.title: Panzer Dragoon II Zwei: Remake Still Happening, Platforms Confirmed
item.content:encoded:
Panzer Dragoon II Zwei: Remake publisher Forever Entertainment has reassured fans that the game is still very much in development, and that a demo will be playable for attendees at this year's Tokyo Game Show.

In a message on social media, the studio revealed that those who visit the Rainy Frog Games booth will be able to check out a demo version of the remake, which, much like the remake of the first game, will sport "modern visuals and remastered music".

As for which platforms you'll be able to play Panzer Dragoon II Zwei: Remake on, Forever says the game will be coming to PC, PlayStation, Xbox, and Nintendo Switch. The studio doesn't mention a native Switch 2 version, unfortunately.

Panzer Dragoon II Zwei: Remake was first announced all the way back in late 2018, along with a remake of its predecessor. That game was released in March 2020, but its sequel has been largely missing in action until now.

You'll be able to enjoy the remake either with the original controls or a new, updated control scheme, and you can also switch between the game's original soundtrack and its newly-arranged version, which was handled by legendary Panzer Dragoon Saga composer Saori Kobayashi.

News of Panzer Dragoon II Zwei: Remake's re-emergence is bittersweet for me; I'm a massive Panzer Dragoon Saga fan, so you can imagine that this news almost feels like one tantalizing step closer to a potential remake of that game.

A remake it would have to be, too, and a ground-up one at that; director Yukio Futatsugi has claimed that publisher Sega has lost the source code for Saga, thus making a remake based on the original code impossible.

In any case, we still don't have a release date for Panzer Dragoon II Zwei: Remake yet, so all of this is pure pipe dream speculation on my part. Stay tuned for more on this.
